conclusion: Objects A and B are released above the tabletop.
Gravity pulls each object straight downward, so they accelerate toward the nearest solid surface beneath them.

The first solid surfaces beneath objects A and B are the tops of the upright rectangular blocks: A descends onto the pair of blocks labelled C and D, and B descends onto the pair of blocks labelled E and F.
On contact, normal-reaction forces from the blocks oppose the weight of A and B, bringing the downward motion to a halt (allowing for a slight bounce if the collisions are not perfectly inelastic).

Once their kinetic energy is dissipated, A and B remain at rest on the block tops, held there by the balance of gravity and the supporting normal forces and prevented from sliding by static friction (assuming the tops are flat and level).
Object A lands on the tops of blocks C/D and comes to rest there; object B lands on the tops of blocks E/F and comes to rest there.
